results.title: Land and sea
results.creator_credit: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keith Payne had a terrible acne problem when he was a youngster but it only got worse when he was deployed into the tropics. Unfortunately for Payne, his attempts to sign up to volunteer in Japan were shot down when the doctors looked at his acne and sent him home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: I've been everywhere
results.creator_credit: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Robert Flisher was excited to leave Australia and see the world as it was his childhood dream to join the Navy. Flisher opens up about his experiences with the Navy and talks about some of the exciting places he visited during his service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Cook's tour
results.creator_credit: Bryan Chipperfield, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Bryan Chipperfield saw no action during his service in the air force. Posted to Calgary in Canada, Chipperfield was able to enjoy skiing, boating and playing sports. Keeping up to date with the war through reading the paper, he knew he may be asked to ‘play his part’ at any time.

Read by fellow veteran Bill Medlyn for Bryan Chipperfield

results.title: A Chance to travel
results.creator_credit: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When George Snowden joined the Australian army, he was given the opportunity to tour Australia. Despite being given the chance to travel across the country, Snowden ended up suffering from a knee injury and was happy to return home after seeing most of the country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [Warnambool veterans]
results.brief_description: Fourteen veterans tell their stories, from the Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy, and the Royal Australian Air Force. They share their memories from World War II, the Korean and Vietnam Wars and from the Australian home front. Ten stories from and four interviews with Victorian veterans based in Port Fairy and Warnambool.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [Warnambool veterans]
results.description: Fourteen veterans tell their stories, from the Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy, and the Royal Australian Air Force. They share their memories from World War II, the Korean and Vietnam Wars and from the Australian home front. Ten stories from and four interviews with Victorian veterans based in Port Fairy and Warnambool.

They share their memories from World War II, the Korean and Vietnam Wars and from the Australian home front. Ten stories from and four interviews with Victorian veterans based in Port Fairy and Warnambool.

results.title: Spuds again
results.brief_description: Irrespresible and cheeky, Avis Quarrell was an avid church goer but liked nothing more than making fun of her superiors. One particular day landed her in hot water and back to peeling spuds.

results.title: A Secret war room
results.creator_credit: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Joan Peck served in the WAAAF as a radio telephone operator at Number one fighter sector in Preston. Their main role was to connect the army, navy and airforce in one central control to help protect and defend the Victorian coastline. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Joan Peck served in the WAAAF as a radio telephone operator at Number one fighter sector in Preston. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.

results.title: Over in 3 weeks
results.creator_credit: Tom Ross, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Once Tom Ross and his fellow soldiers settled in Singapore, the bombing started. In three weeks, they were captured and sent to Changi, where Ross was a prisoner of war for three and a half years. Despite the abject conditions, Ross managed to survive through sheer determination and will to live.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Ross, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

In three weeks, they were captured and sent to Changi, where Ross was a prisoner of war for three and a half years. Despite the abject conditions, Ross managed to survive through sheer determination and will to live.

Despite the abject conditions, Ross managed to survive through sheer determination and will to live.

results.title: My brother's birthday
results.creator_credit: Max Hammond, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In Syria, on the way to Beirut, Max Hammond’s thoughts turned to his family. One of seven children, Hammond and his three brothers served together in World War II. He recounts a close call that occurred on his brother’s birthday and reflects on how lucky he and his brothers are.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Max Hammond, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Miss Navy
results.creator_credit: Margaret Morton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Margaret Morton’s first time in the navy was short lived, as she contracted pneumonia which further developed into tuberculosis, just six months after joining. This meant Margaret spent an extended period of time hospitalised and in isolation, an experience she found frustrating and lonely. Morton describes the memories she still holds dear from her short time in service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Morton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Margaret Morton’s first time in the navy was short lived, as she contracted pneumonia which further developed into tuberculosis, just six months after joining. This meant Margaret spent an extended period of time hospitalised and in isolation, an experience she found frustrating and lonely. Morton describes the memories she still holds dear from her short time in service.
description_for_label: Margaret Morton’s first time in the navy was short lived, as she contracted pneumonia which further developed into tuberculosis, just six months after joining. This meant Margaret spent an extended period of time hospitalised and in isolation, an experience she found frustrating and lonely. Morton describes the memories she still holds dear from her short time in service.
